title: An Introduction to Space Systems
text:
1 Introduction
Welcome to An Introduction to Space Systems. This book is a personal journey through the principles, mathematics, and technologies behind satellite missions.
You may start reading from any chapter, but we recommend beginning with Orbital Mechanics. If you want to learn about ADCS, then we recommend ADCS
See Equation Equation 1.1 and Section Section 1.1 for examples of references.

title: An Introduction to Space Systems
text:
1.1 The Structure of This Book
This book is divided into two parts:

Orbital Mechanics: Basics of orbits, coordinate systems, and orbital elements.
Satellite Subsystems: ADCS, power, communication, and more.

title: 2  Geocentric Coordinate Systems
text:
3 Overview
Geocentric coordinate systems are centered at the Earth’s center. This chapter introduces the geocentric equatorial frame and related systems.
See also the orbital elements in Section ?sec-orb-elements.

title: 2  Geocentric Coordinate Systems
text:
3.1 Coordinate Frames
We define a right-handed coordinate system with:

X-axis pointing toward the vernal equinox
Z-axis along the Earth’s rotation axis

title: 2  Geocentric Coordinate Systems
text:
3.2 Example Equation
The position vector \(\vec{r}\) can be expressed as:
\[
\vec{r} = x \hat{i} + y \hat{j} + z \hat{k}
\tag{3.1}\]

title: 4  Attitude Determination and Control
text:
5 Introduction
The ADCS subsystem is responsible for controlling a satellite’s orientation.
We build on the orbital reference frames defined in Geocentric Coordinate Systems.

title: 4  Attitude Determination and Control
text:
5.1 Euler Angles
Attitude can be described using Euler angles \((\phi, \theta, \psi)\).
The transformation matrix is:
\[
R =
\begin{bmatrix}
c_\psi c_\theta & c_\psi s_\theta s_\phi - s_\psi c_\phi & c_\psi s_\theta c_\phi + s_\psi s_\phi \\
s_\psi c_\theta & s_\psi s_\theta s_\phi + c_\psi c_\phi & s_\psi s_\theta c_\phi - c_\psi s_\phi \\
-s_\theta & c_\theta s_\phi & c_\theta c_\phi
\end{bmatrix}
\tag{5.1}\]
where \(c\) and \(s\) denote cosine and sine functions respectively.
Refer to Equation Equation 5.1 for attitude rotation.
Refer to Equation 3.1 for orbital period.
